title: Anne Boleyn (TV series)
text:
Anne Boleyn is a British three-part psychological thriller miniseries developed for <a href="Channel%205%20%28British%20TV%20channel%29">Channel 5</a> starring <a href="Jodie%20Turner-Smith">Jodie Turner-Smith</a> as <a href="Anne%20Boleyn">the titular role</a>. It was written by Eve Hedderwick Turner and directed by Lynsey Miller with historian <a href="Dan%20Jones%20%28writer%29">Dan Jones</a> as executive producer.
Premise.
The series is set in Anne's final five months prior to her execution by beheading for treason in 1536.
Production.
Development.
<a href="Ben%20Frow">Ben Frow</a> of <a href="Channel%205%20%28British%20TV%20channel%29">Channel 5</a> first mentioned the project at the <a href="Edinburgh%20Fringe%20Festival">Edinburgh Fringe Festival</a> in summer 2020. The three-part "convention-defying" series from Fable Pictures was officially announced in October 2020, with Eve Hedderwick Turner as writer and Lynsey Miller as director. Faye Ward and Hannah Farrell of Fable produced and historian <a href="Dan%20Jones%20%28writer%29">Dan Jones</a> executive produced. The series "sets out to examine Anne Boleyn's life through a <a href="Feminism">feminist</a> lens as she struggles to conceive a boy heir and pushback against the <a href="Patriarchy">society</a> she was born into."
Casting.
In October 2020, it was announced with the series that <a href="Jodie%20Turner-Smith">Jodie Turner-Smith</a> would star as <a href="Anne%20Boleyn">Anne Boleyn</a> with <a href="Paapa%20Essiedu">Paapa Essiedu</a>, <a href="Amanda%20Burton">Amanda Burton</a>, <a href="Thalissa%20Teixeira">Thalissa Teixeira</a>, <a href="Barry%20Ward%20%28actor%29">Barry Ward</a>, and <a href="Jamael%20Westman">Jamael Westman</a> also set to feature. <a href="Mark%20Stanley">Mark Stanley</a> joined the cast as <a href="Henry%20VIII">Henry VIII</a> in November.
Filming.
Principal photography took place in <a href="Yorkshire">Yorkshire</a> over six weeks, finishing in December 2020. Filming locations included <a href="Castle%20Howard">Castle Howard</a> in <a href="North%20Yorkshire">North Yorkshire</a>, <a href="Bolton%20Castle">Bolton Castle</a> in <a href="Wensleydale">Wensleydale</a>, <a href="Bolton%20Abbey">Bolton Abbey</a> in <a href="Wharfedale">Wharfedale</a>, <a href="Oakwell%20Hall">Oakwell Hall</a> in <a href="Birstall%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Birstall</a>, St Michael's Church in <a href="Emley%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Emley</a>, <a href="Harewood%20House">Harewood House</a> in <a href="Harewood%2C%20West%20Yorkshire">Harewood</a>, and <a href="Ripley%20Castle">Ripley Castle</a> in <a href="Ripley%2C%20North%20Yorkshire">Ripley</a>.
Release.
The first episode premiered in the UK on <a href="Channel%205%20%28British%20TV%20channel%29">Channel 5</a> on 1 June 2021. <a href="Sony%20Pictures%20Television">Sony Pictures Television</a> co-financed the project with Channel 5 and distributed the series internationally. The drama was released in the United States on <a href="AMC%2B">AMC+</a> and on <a href="Crave%20%28streaming%20service%29">Crave</a> in Canada.
Reception.
Review aggregator <a href="Rotten%20Tomatoes">Rotten Tomatoes</a> reported an approval rating of 53% based on 17 critic reviews, with an average rating of 6.2/10. The website's critics consensus reads, "Though the show around her isn't quite up to snuff, there's no denying the pleasure of Jodie Turner-Smith's powerful turn as the one-and-only Anne Boleyn."
"<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" and "<a href="The%20Independent">The Independent</a>" both gave the drama 3 stars out 5. <a href="Lucy%20Mangan">Lucy Mangan</a> of the former said the series "works" but criticised its "silly surplus of metaphors" and portrayal of Henry. Adam White of the latter found the show a "soapy romp" but that it made sense for the story being told. Turner-Smith's performance was widely praised. Beth Webb of "<a href="Empire%20%28film%20magazine%29">Empire</a>" called the series a "showcase of Jodie Turner-Smith's resilience as a performer" and mentioned how the "small but well-assembled supporting cast elevates her performance".
There was criticism of <a href="Black-washing">Black-washing</a>, as some of the actors were <a href="Black%20people">Black</a> and the characters portrayed were <a href="White%20people">white</a>. The <a href="Radio%20Times">Radio Times</a> described this as "identity-conscious casting" and quoted the actor <a href="Mark%20Stanley">Mark Stanley</a>: "It was all about this being the right person for the job, rather than what we as a society might perceive as the ‘right look’ for the job".
